anchor.surface_text: Forgery is defined in s. 463, I.P.C. according to which whoever makes a false document or part of a document with intent to cause damage or injury to the public or to any person or to support any claim or title or to cause any person to part with property or to enter into any express or implied contract or with intent to commit fraud or that fraud may be committed, commits forgery.

concepts.interpretation: Making false document with intent to cause damage, injury, fraud etc.

holdings.text: The application under s. 561-A, Cr. P.C. should have been disposed of after hearing the appellant's counsel and its disposal without such hearing was clearly wrong and unjust.

anchor.surface_text: We would, however, like to point out that the application under s. 561-A, Cr. P.C. should have been disposed of after hearing the appellants counsel and its disposal without such hearing was clearly wrong and unjust. The appellant has a just grievance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disposal in chambers without affording opportunity to be heard violates principles of natural justice; appellant has right to reasonable opportunity.

holdings.text: Section 133 Evidence Act permits conviction on uncorroborated accomplice testimony, but illustration (b) to s.114 requires corroboration in material particulars as rule of prudence.

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the second point we may first state the legal position relating to the testimony of an approver. Section 133, Indian Evidence Act, which falls in Ch. IX dealing generally with witnesses, expressly provides that an accomplice is a competent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of s.133 and illus(b) s.114; approver suspect witness needing corroboration connecting accused to crime to ensure reliability.

holdings.text: Appellant's conviction under s.467 IPC wholly unsustainable on existing evidence as approver's testimony uninspiring and lacking corroboration in material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: In face of this material, we find that the appellants conviction under s. 467. I.P.C. is wholly unsustainable on the existing evidence. The approvers testimony is most uninspiring and there is no corroboration worth the name.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No independent evidence of forgery or falsity of pattas/signatures; defence witnesses (DW1, DW2) confirm genuineness contradicting approver.

holdings.text: Charge of criminal conspiracy under s.120B IPC not proved as no reliable evidence of agreement or acts in pursuance; approver's evidence rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the charge of criminal conspiracy under s. 120-B, I.P.C. as a separate and distinct offence independent of the offence under s. 467, I.P.C. No doubt in almost every case of conspiracy it is generally a matter of inference

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conspiracy inferred from acts in pursuance, but underlying forgery evidence rejected; approver unreliable on conspiracy too.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; appellant acquitted of offences under ss.467 and 120B IPC.
